moves.1. e4 c5 2. d4 cxd4 3. Qxd4 Nc6 4. Qd1 N: I'm playing a very characteristic Sicilian Dragon opening.  Knights are all in the right spot, the c pawn is gone, the d and g pawns are in position, and the black bishop fianchettoed nicely.  I mostly got this from "How to Think Ahead in Chess".
moves.9. O-O Be6: I was out of things to develop, and I wanted to open up the rook's file.  In this situation, white can choose between letting his white bishop run around and waste tempo, or he can just trade and double up pawns on the e file.  He chose to trade off.
moves.13. Rb1 Nxe3 14. fxe3: Since I'm ahead, trading off pieces and opening up lines (even for the opposition) makes sense.  Also, now he's got double isolated pawns.
moves.14... Rc8 15. Ng5: Putting pressure on the doubled pawn.
moves.15... Ne5 16. Nxe6: Forked like a rookie.  How disgraceful.
moves.16... Qb6 17. Qd5: Preparing for a revealed check, but in my humble opinion taking the rook might have been wiser.
moves.17... Qxe3+ 18. Kh1 Rxf1+ 19. Rxf1: Now I've gotten the rook out of danger and taken the pawn back, so the beautiful fork comes to nothing.
moves.30... Kg7: This attack just ran out of steam, but I've succeeded in trading off pieces while maintaining my advantage.
My bishop advantage proves enough for the checkmate.
